title.narrative: Monitoring the long-term effects of poaching on elephants in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: In response to widespread elephant poaching throughout southern Tanzania, this organization is working to protect a key population near Tanzanias elephant strongholds of Selous and Ruaha. Activities will include training staff from Tanzanias wildlife research institute, TAWIRI, assessing four elephant populations for early warning signs of decline, and training national park staff in monitoring elephant populations and conducting anti-poaching activities.

title.narrative: Support USAID Priorities-Tanzania

description.narrative: This project will strengthen the institutional capacity of the Community Based Conservation Training Centre (CBCTC) staff to adequately train Village Game Scouts to protect wildlife in the Greater Selous Ecosystem, Tanzania. The major outputs are the development of a strategic plan and new curriculum for the CBCTC based on a participatory assessment with stakeholders. Activities include creating new user-friendly course and resource materials including a Tool Kit for Village Game Scouts that also serves as a teaching tool for CBCTC trainers, providing training equipment, and making infrastructure improvements.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conserving kipunji Rungwecebus kipunji strongholds in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Conserving kipunji Rungwecebus kipunji strongholds in Southern Tanzania. In partnership with Wildlife Conservation Society this project will support the long-term survival of the Kipunji in the Mount Rungwe and Livingstone forests in Tanzania. Specific activities include: employ forest guards to improve law enforcement in both the Livingston and Mt Rungwe forests and will ensure patrol areas will be surveyed on a continuous basis; (2) address the root cause of forest degredation by developing alternative fuels sources with locally managed woodlots that will provide 75% of required wood to villages and will pilot the use of fuel efficient stoves; (3) reduce human-monkey conflict by developing an effective crop raiding mitigation methods to reduce retributional hunting; (4) Determine appropriate cash crops to plant adjacent to the forest to reduce hunting threats; (5) conduct environmental education and outreach on the importance of the forest in 20 villages.

title.narrative: Support USAID Priorities-Tanzania

description.narrative: This grant will support ongoing protection and monitoring of Mkomazi National Park's fenced rhino sanctuary. Funds will be used to support security and rhino monitoring salaries and expenses, aerial surveillance in the area, specialized training for park personnel, and maintenance of essential infrastructure for the rhino sanctuary including fencing, boreholes for water supply and security outposts.

title.narrative: Support USAID Priorities-Tanzania

description.narrative: Funds will support rhino-focused environmental education programs in and around Mkomazi National Park in northern Tanzania. Specific activities will include visits by the Mkomazi education team to local schools and communities, support for local wildlife clubs, and trips on the custom-built and specially equipped Rafiki wa Faru (Friends of Rhino) education bus by students and community members into Mkomazi National Park and the education center. Ongoing training and mentorship of the local education officers and an exchange visit to the rhino education program in Zambia are also supported.

title.narrative: Protecting Tanzanias elephant populations through the expansion of new and innovative law..enforcement methods

description.narrative: To improve anti-poaching, Tanzania is implementing a law enforcement monitoring system using SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) software in Ruaha, Katavi and Tarangire National Park. Funds will be used to train rangers in SMART data collection methods while on patrol, and training and ongoing support for dedicated on-site SMART data managers at each of the three parks, and in deploying a network of camera traps for detection of illegal activities.

title.narrative: Economic assessment of the current value of wildlife in Tanzania

description.narrative: The goal of this study is to obtain a current understanding of the conomic value of the trophy hunting industry in Tanzania. The information will be used to raise the awareness of the economic importance of the wildlife industry to Tanzania's national economy, especially to rural economies. The GOT and private sector will be encouraged to improve the long term sustainable conservation of wildlife through a better understanding and appreciation of its value and role.

title.narrative: Continuing support for community-based conservation of the kipunji (Rungwecebus kipunji) in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: This project will focus on long-term survival of the kipunji in the Mount Rungwe and Livingstone forests in the Southern Highlands of Tanzania. Specific objectives include: (1) Reduce loss and degradation of kipunji forest habitat in the Rungwe-Livingstone forests; (2) Reduce retaliatory hunting of kipunji by farmers around the Rungwe-Livingstone forests; (3) Protect an isolated kipunji subpopulation by supporting a newly initiated community forest conservation program in an unmanaged village forest in Livingstone.

title.narrative: Evaluating the Efficacy of Conservation Drone Technology for Chimpanzee Monitoring in..Western Tanzania

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the efficacy of using Conservation Drones to monitor chimpanzee populations in Western Tanzania. The recipient will compare chimpanzee nest densities along the same transects using two different survey methods (ground, UAV); and determine the costs associated with each method to cover the same survey area to evaluate which method will be most cost-effective for future monitoring.

title.narrative: Investigation into the potential use of African giant pouched rats (Cricetomys ansorgei) to detect illegal timber and pangolins in shipping containers.

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to counter wildlife trafficking in ports by using African giant pouched rats (Cricetomys ansorgei) to detect timber (hardwoods) and.pangolin skin and scales in shipping containers. This project plans to provide proof of principle that this is possible and would be the first phase of a much larger project to mainstream rats as an innovative tool in combatting illegal wildlife trade. This project is intended to conserve hardwood and pangolin species by addressing the impacts of wildlife trafficking in shipping containers, which are used to smuggle large volumes of wildlife contraband such as timber hardwoods) and pangolins. Specific activities include: (1) testing the rats in a laboratory environment for their ability to discriminate between the target substances of timber (hardwoods) and pangolin skin and scales and a wide variety of other control substances; (2) developing an appropriate indication mechanism; (3) assessing the best operational option for the rats to detect hardwoods and pangolins in containers, comparing success rates of direct detection at the vents, or detection of filters sampled through the vents."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Never again: strengthening long-term protection of elephants in southern Tanzania

description.narrative: Funds will be used to minimize conflict with local farmers in the farming communities of Namelok and Isinet between Amboseli, Chyulu Hills and Tsavo West National Parks. Specific activity will include the construction of a 59-km electric fence to keep elephants inside wildlife-tolerant areas. According to the impact assessment and community consultation, this fence will prevent elephants from entering agricultural land and, in exchange, the community will tolerate elephant movement through existing corridors and into seasonal dispersal areas in order to minimize conflict and facilitate coexistence.Ensuring long-term viability of elephants through exclusion fencing to permanently reduce human-elephant conflict in the Greater Amboseli Ecosystem, Kenya

title.narrative: Generating local support for elephant conservation near Ruaha National Park, Tanzania

description.narrative: This ongoing project aims to increase tolerance of elephants in and around Ruaha National Park by assisting local farmers in preventing elephant damage to crops, by conducting outreach and park visitation programs to improve understanding of the importance of the park and by providing opportunities for dialogue between park officials and local residents. Activities will include assisting farmers with constructing beehive fences to deter elephants, conducting education and outreach programs in villages, and operating a park visitation program for local residents to visit Ruaha and meet with park officials.

title.narrative: Protecting elephants and elephant corridors around Katavi National Park and adjacent reserves

description.narrative: The project is working to improve the security of the elephant population in southern Katavi National Park, Lwafi Game Reserve, and Loasi River and Kalambo Forest Reserves by engaging communities around the reserves, the Tanzania Forest Service, and district government. Activities will include: designing forest and corridor management plans, aerial survey of large mammals, biological monitoring, human-elephant conflict mitigation, training park and district staff, and demarcating reserve boundaries.

title.narrative: Strengthening community-based chimpanzee protection and monitoring in key village forests in the Greater Mahale Ecosystem, western Tanzania

description.narrative: The purpose of this 1-year project is to empower a local community-based organization, the Tongwe Trust, to conserve the eastern chimpanzee in Tanzania. Specific activities include: 1) improving patrols and surveillance in the Nkata Forest to enhance chimpanzee protection; 2) partnering with the Ugalla Primate Project for monitoring implementation to increase understanding of chimpanzee populations, human activities, and threats to chimpanzees; 3) generating greater community support for chimpanzee conservation through education and forest management planning; and 4) developing the capacity of Tongwe Trust to sustainably manage and develop the project.

title.narrative: CHIMPANZEES AND FIRES: ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF ANNUAL FIRES ON CHIMPANZEES AND CRITICAL CHIMPANZEE HABITAT IN WESTERN TANZANIA

description.narrative: IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LIVERPOOL JOHN MOORES UNIVERSITY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT PROTECTION OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES BY ESTABLISHING BASELINE DATA ON THE EFFECT OF ANNUAL BURNING ON CHIMPANZEE HABITAT AND BEHAVIOR IN WESTERN TANZANIA, AND DISSEMINATING FINDINGS FOR INTEGRATION INTO FIRE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) IDENTIFYING LANDSCAPE FEATURES THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH BURNING PATTERNS ACROSS THE GREATER MAHALE ECOSYSTEM 2) IDENTIFYING AREAS OF OVERLAP BETWEEN BURNING AND CHIMPANZEE HABITAT USE 3) IDENTIFYING THE EFFECT OF BURNING ON VEGETATION AND ESTABLISHING MONTHLY MONITORING AND 4) SPONSORING AND TRAINING A POST-GRADUATE MSC STUDENT IN GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF DAR ES SALAAM.

title.narrative: Engaging the communities living around Mkomazi National Park to foster support for black rhino conservation initiatives in Tanzania

description.narrative: This proposal focuses on an outreach program to promote conservation of the most endangered black rhino subspecies, the Eastern black rhino (Diceros bicornis michaeli), in Mkomazi National Park in Tanzania (the country where they are most threatened - fewer than one hundred rhinos remain). This conservation education program, Rafiki wa Faru (friends of rhinos), runs an environmental education program, on board a custom built bus that functions as classroom, library, and safari vehicle in order to promote conservation and environmental awareness within villages bordering the national parks. The educators on board this bus visit communities near Mkomazi and present materials about the biology and economic importance of Tanzanias wildlife. This proposal requests funds for its ongoing running costs for the period July 2018 to June 2020 inclusive, during which the program will reach 730 school children, conduct 26 visits to Mkomazi, and develop and distribute a new Activity Book for teachers.

title.narrative: Enhancing human-elephant coexistence in Selous-Udzungwa, Tanzania

description.narrative: Ten years ago, Southern Tanzania was home to the second largest elephant population in Africa: more than 100,000 elephants moved between Mikumi and Udzungwa National Parks and the Selous Game Reserve. Now, they number fewer than 16,000 and the connections between the protected areas are being severed by human settlement, infrastructure development, and agriculture. This project will identify corridors that are still viable for elephant connectivity between the protected areas by mapping elephant movement and land use and working to get these corridors protected status. Secondly, the grantee will work to alleviate human-elephant conflict in key villages by deploying various methods to minimize crop raiding and conflict and to improve livelihoods through income-generating coexistence interventions.

title.narrative: Support for black rhinoceros conservation in Serengeti National Park, Ngorongoro Conservation Area and adjacent dispersal areas, Tanzania

description.narrative: Eastern black rhinos (Diceros bicornis michaeli) have disappeared from all of Tanzania except Mkomazi National Park, Serengeti National Park, and Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The few surviving rhinos continue to be under severe threat. USFWS previously supported all three sites throughout the 1990s, but had to terminate funding due to questionable performance and lack of commitment from the host country government. Now, an international non-governmental organization has stepped in to reinitiate and reinvigorate rhino protection programs. This years funds will support black rhino monitoring and protection, improve communications between wildlife authorities and community wildlife management areas (WMAs) and Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya.

title.narrative: Enhancement of black rhinoceros monitoring and protection in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania

description.narrative: The black rhino population of the Serengeti Mara Ecosystem has been severely depleted by armed poachers seeking rhino horn. The Tanzanian portion of the ecosystem contains surviving subpopulations near the border with Kenya in the north, in the central Ndasiata region, and at Moru Kopjes in the south. Funds will be used to reinvigorate a rhino protection program including technical and material support to tag and track individual rhinos, to deploy camera traps at areas frequented by rhinos, and to equip and deploy anti-poaching teams specifically to protect rhino range.

title.narrative: GENERATING LOCAL SUPPORT FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION NEAR RUAHA NATIONAL PARK, TANZANIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build local community support for elephant conservation in villages surrounding Tanzanias Ruaha National Park and the adjacent Lunda-Mkwambi Wildlife Management Area, including building their resistance to poaching networks seeking assistance from the communities to illegally hunt and kill elephants for their ivory. Where people perceive no benefits from elephant conservation, communities can be sources of labor for organized poachers and human-elephant conflict can create severe antagonism towards the species. This project works to alter that perception by building partnerships with the local communities that live around one of East Africas largest remaining elephant populations. Specific activities include: (1) park visitation by residents of villages adjacent to Ruaha National Park, including engagement with park personnel and educational programs; (2) development of beehive fencing to address human-elephant conflict; and (3) public engagement and delivery of an established conservation education curriculum, including teacher training and knowledge assessments as well as conservation film showings in villages that have experienced human-elephant conflict and poaching.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING LONG-TERM PROTECTION OF ELEPHANTS IN SOUTHERN TANZANIA - 2

description.narrative: Tanzania lost over half its elephant between 2006 and 2015 (Thouless et al, 2016). The majority of these .losses occurred in southern Tanzania, particularly the Ruaha-Rungwa and Selous-Mikumi ecosystems. .These declines were driven by demand for ivory, as well as insufficient resources, personnel, capacity and .information for adequate protection of southern Tanzanias vast protected areas. .Since 2014, Southern Tanzania Elephant Program (STEP) has worked to increase protection for elephants .in the Ruaha-Rungwa ecosystem by building the capacity and resources of protected areas, increasing .access to conservation technologies, expanding patrol coverage through aerial surveillance, increasing the .effectiveness of patrols through mapping and analysis of law enforcement data, and conducting applied .elephant monitoring and research to identify priority areas for protection efforts. Significant progress has .been made under the current AECF grant to STEP (September 2017 September 2019; F17AP00448). This .Award will continue and expand this work for a further two years.

title.narrative: STRENGTHENING LONG-TERM PROTECTION OF ELEPHANTS IN SOUTHERN TANZANIA - 2

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in the Rungwa-Kizigo-Muhesi Game Reserve complex, Nyerere National Park, Udzungwa Mountains National Park, and the Kilombero Valley, by improving human-elephant coexistence and enhancing local livelihoods. As part of the larger Western Tanzania Region and Selous-Niassa Region savanna elephant strongholds, this landscape is home to an estimated 31,000 elephants. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants and their habitat by addressing the impacts of human-elephant conflict (HEC) and poaching. Specific activities include: (1) monitoring and mitigating HEC through community-based data collection, beehive and solar-powered strobe light fence construction, and improved crop storage; (2) training rangers to document and report HEC incidents in the communities; (3) conducting community engagement and outreach, including Swahili-language human-elephant coexistence films; and (4) supporting a community loan and insurance program and alternative livelihoods development.

title.narrative: REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - CONSERVATION OF CHIMPANZEES IN SOUTHERN TANGANYIKA ECOSYSTEM

description.narrative: Funds under this award are to be used to secure the long-term protection of chimpanzees in Tanzanias South Tanganyika region by increasing understanding of chimpanzee population status and geographical distribution, and reducing chimpanzee habitat loss. Activities include: 1) updating the chimpanzee population estimate for the region; 2) mapping chimpanzee distribution; 3) determining the current condition of chimpanzee habitats; 4) supporting patrols by Tanzania Forest Services, Tanzania Wildlife Authority, and local government authorities to ensure wildlife conservation; 5) establishing land-use plans in two villages that pose a high threat to chimpanzees; 6) conducting stakeholder workshops on the ecological importance of chimpanzees; and 7) raising community awareness of the conservation value of chimpanzees.

title.narrative: SECURING CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION IN THE MAHALE - TONGWE WEST CORRIDOR

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO STRENGTHEN THE PROTECTION OF HIGH BIODIVERSITY FORESTS AND ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEE POPULATIONS IN THE MAHALE TONGWE WEST CORRIDOR OF TANZANIA BY IMPROVING THE CAPACITY OF VILLAGES TO PROTECT VILLAGE FORESTS IN THE CORRIDOR WHILE DERIVING SUSTAINABLE INCOME FROM THEM. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) ENGAGING TWO KEY VILLAGES TO INTRODUCE THE PROJECT AND OBTAIN COMMUNITY INPUT 2) ENGAGING COMMUNITIES IN PARTICIPATORY FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING DEMARCATION OF VILLAGE FORESTS 3) CHOOSING VILLAGE FOREST SCOUTS AND AGREEING ON FOREST USE RESTRICTIONS 4) IDENTIFYING FOREST AREAS FOR SUSTAINABLE INCOME GENERATION ACTIVITIES 5) ASSISTING COMMUNITIES IN DEVELOPING BYLAWS FOR THE PROTECTION OF VILLAGE FORESTS 5) IDENTIFYING SUPPLEMENTARY INCOME STREAMS FOR DEVELOPMENT, INCLUDING AN ECO 1 TOURISM FACILITY AND CARBON-BASED INCOME GENERATION AND 6) ESTABLISHING A RANGER POST FOR USE BY VILLAGE FOREST SCOUTS.

title.narrative: SECURING CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION IN THE MAHALE - TONGWE WEST CORRIDOR

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to strengthen the protection of high biodiversity forests and endangered chimpanzee populations in the Mahale Tongwe West corridor of Tanzania by improving the capacity of villages to protect village forests in the corridor while deriving sustainable income from them. Activities include: 1) engaging two key villages to introduce the project and obtain community input; 2) engaging communities in participatory forest management activities, including demarcation of village forests; 3) choosing village forest scouts and agreeing on forest use restrictions; 4) identifying forest areas for sustainable income generation activities; 5) assisting communities in developing bylaws for the protection of village forests; 5) identifying supplementary income streams for development, including an eco.tourism facility and carbon-based income generation; and 6) establishing a ranger post for use by village forest scouts.

title.narrative: CONSERVING THE NGORONGORO BLACK RHINO POPULATION IN NORTHERN TANZANIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in Ngorongoro, Tanzania by studying and monitoring the black rhinoceros population to meet growth targets based on rigorous scientific data for long-term viability. This project is intended to conserve the Eastern black rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing the lack of metapopulation analysis and management in a changing landscape. Specific activities include: (1) designing a long-term monitoring program; and (2) analyzing habitat use and diet to assess the ecological carrying capacity in Ngorongoro Conservation Area for the improvement of black rhinoceros monitoring and management for the future.

title.narrative: SUPPORT OF BLACK RHINOCEROS MONITORING AND PROTECTION IN THE GREATER SERENGETI ECOSYSTEM AND MKOMAZI NATIONAL PARK, NORTHERN TANZANIA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in the Greater Serengeti Ecosystem and Mkomazi National Park, northern Tanzania by providing technical and material support for monitoring and protection in order to ensure the long-term survival of important black rhinoceros populations. This project is intended to conserve the Eastern black rhinoceros and their habitat by addressing the impacts of poaching and the loss of tourism revenue due to the worldwide COVID-19 pandemic. Specific activities include: (1) providing field equipment and repairing vehicles for rhinoceros protection teams; (2) monitoring rhinoceros populations; (3) upgrading infrastructure; (4) improving water provision; and (5) facilitating communications among stakeholders.

title.narrative: SUPPORT TO TANZANIA WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY IN THE PROTECTION OF AFRICAN ELEPHANTS

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain anti-poaching pressure in a severely depleted elephant population in central Tanzania. Elephants in the Selous ecosystem were estimated at over 100,000 individuals in 1976, declining by 85% in 2014 to approximately 15,000 animals. The most recent wave of poaching pressure peaked between 2010 and 2013 with an estimated six elephants killed each day. Poaching has since stabilized to about two elephants killed every month in the Selous Game Reserve, one of the largest protected areas in Africa, where reserve staff and patrol teams are responsible for controlling illegal activities across an area nearly the size of West Virginia. This project builds on sustained anti-poaching efforts to provide essential security for elephants and to work towards the stabilization and recovery of one of Tanzanias largest elephant populations. Specific activities include: (1) aerial surveillance and support, including fuel and maintenance, and operations; (2) improvement of communications network, including installation of radio equipment that expands the network to additional reserve sectors; (3) ground surveillance and protection support, including transport, ranger operations, and a mobile team to respond rapidly to illegal activities and incidents of human-wildlife conflict.

title.narrative: IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF THE ELEPHANTS OF THE KATAVI NATIONAL PARK TRANSBOUNDARY AREA AND THEIR HABITAT

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN KATAVI NATIONAL PARK AND LWAFI GAME RESERVE BY IMPROVING TRANSBOUNDARY ELEPHANT MANAGEMENT BETWEEN TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA AND ENHANCING LOCAL PARTNER ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE LARGER WESTERN TANZANIA REGION SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO THE LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS IN EAST AFRICA, WITH AN ESTIMATED 20,145 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, AND HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC). SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY BASED CAMERA TRAP MONITORING AND MAPPING OF TRANSBOUNDARY ELEPHANT MOVEMENTS (2) ORGANIZING COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDER COORDINATION MEETINGS AND TECHNICAL AND COMMUNITY EXCHANGE VISITS BETWEEN TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA AND (3) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY BASED HEC MITIGATION PLANNING AND TRAINING.

title.narrative: GENERATING LOCAL SUPPORT FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION NEAR RUAHA NATIONAL PARK, TANZANIA- 4

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support an elephant conservation effort in Ruaha National Park and.surrounding villages in the greater Ruaha-Rungwa ecosystem by improving human-elephant coexistence.and building a constituency for elephant conservation. As part of the larger Western Tanzania Region.savanna elephant stronghold, this ecosystem is home to the largest population of elephants in East Africa,.with an estimated 20,145 individuals. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants and.their habitat by addressing the impacts of human-elephant conflict (HEC) and poaching. Specific.activities include: (1) organizing park visitation and alternative livelihood opportunities for local.communities living with elephants; (2) constructing beehive barrier fences to reduce elephant crop.raiding; (3) systematically monitoring HEC events; and (4) conducting community outreach and.education programming through primary schools and conservation film screenings with villages.identified as HEC hotspots.

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE RUNGWA KIZIGO MUHESI GAME RESERVE COMPLEX, NYERERE NATIONAL PARK, UDZUNGWA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK, AND THE KILOMBERO VALLEY, BY IMPROVING HUMAN ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE AND ENHANCING LOCAL LIVELIHOODS. title.narrative: HOLISTICALLY ENHANCING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE FOR TWO PRIORITY ELEPHANT POPULATIONS IN TANZANIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in the Rungwa-Kizigo-Muhesi Game.Reserve complex, Nyerere National Park, Udzungwa Mountains National Park, and the Kilombero.Valley, by improving human-elephant coexistence and enhancing local livelihoods. As part of the larger.Western Tanzania Region and Selous-Niassa Region savanna elephant strongholds, this landscape is.home to an estimated 31,000 elephants. This project is intended to conserve African savanna elephants.and their habitat by addressing the impacts of human-elephant conflict (HEC) and poaching. Specific.activities include: (1) monitoring and mitigating HEC through community-based data collection, beehive.and solar-powered strobe light fence construction, and improved crop storage; (2) training rangers to.document and report HEC incidents in the communities; (3) conducting community engagement and.outreach, including Swahili-language human-elephant coexistence films; and (4) supporting a community.loan and insurance program and alternative livelihoods development.
